OVERVIEW
Alt-QM guidelines are structured to guide its users towards making common sense lending decisions on loans to borrowers who may have limited access to credit. These borrower's situations generally require the consideration of alternative forms of documenting income and/or compensating factors which offset the risk indicated by a recent credit event or elevated debt-to-income ratio. The borrower's ability to repay must be proven in all instances.
Loans eligible for sale to a Government Sponsored Entity (Federal National Mortgage Association ("Fannie Mae" or “FNMA") or Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation ("Freddie Mac" or "FHLMC") are not eligible for the Alt-QM programs.
For any guideline not addressed in these guides, defer to Fannie Mae Guidelines.

Alternative Income Documentation Types*
Asset Depletion
The minimum eligible assets required is the lower of $500,000 or 100% of the subject loan amount. Qualification is determined solely based on the Applicant's liquid assets and assets they can liquidate without restriction. Assets must be seasoned a minimum of 30 days. Assets being considered must be verified with the most recent one (1) month account statement(s), quarterly statement(s), or VOD. All individuals listed on the asset account(s) must be on the Note and Mortgage. Calculation Method: Qualifying income is based upon the total assets eligible for depletion, less down payment, less out of pocket closing costs, divided by 60.
12 Months Bank Statements
Income calculated based on 12 months recent Business or Personal bank statements. Refer to program guidelines for calculation methods available. Bank statements should show a stable or increasing trend. If the trend is declining and/or irregular, additional documentation may be required up to and including an additional 12 months of statements.
1099 Only
Validated most recent 1 year 1099. Borrower must receive compensation either in the form of commissions or as an independent contractor. An expense ratio must be developed using one of the two below methods. Method 1: Utilize 10% baseline expense factor. Multiply the expense ratio by the gross receipts shown on the 1099. Method 2: Provide a CPA letter stating the business' expense ratio based on the most recent year's tax return. Multiply the expense ratio by the gross receipts shown on the 1099.
W2 Only
Validated most recent year W2 and current VOE used as qualifying income. Refer to guidelines for specific guidance and requirements.
1 Yr. Tax Retum
Filed most recent year tax returns to be utilized for income qualifying. Refer to guidelines for specific guidance and requirements.
P&L Only
12-24 Month CPA, EA,PTIN or CTEC compiled P&L Statement - minimum 50% business ownership required. Qualifying income is the net income from the P&L divided by the time period covered multiped by the borrower's ownership percentage.
WVOE Only
2 year employment history required, with YTD written VOE. EWVOE does not require bank statements to support. Wage Earner/Commission borrowers only.
Supplemental Income
Most Alternative Income Options notated above include additional supplemental income options such as Asset Assist, rental income, RSU income, retirement/pension, social security and/or additional coborrower income. Please refer to the guidelines for additional information.

Appraisal
Loan amounts over $2,000,000 automatically require two appraisals. Every appraisal requires a Desk Review. Properties with a condition rating of C5 or C6 or a quality rating of Q6 are not acceptable.

Credit
Standard three (3) tradelines reporting for a minimum of 12 months with activity within the last 12 months, or at least two (2) tradelines reporting for a minimum of 24 months with activity within the last 12 months. If the primary borrower has three (3) credit scores, the minimum tradeline requirement is waived. Qualifying FICO = the FICO of the Primary Wage Earner which will be the score used for pricing

Not permitted on Investment Property transactions. Cannot be used for reserves or when utilizing Asset Depletion for income. Refer to guides for all other requirements

Property insurance for loans must protect against loss or damage from fire and other hazards covered by the standard extended coverage endorsement. The coverage must provide for claims to be settled on a replacement cost basis. Extended coverage must include, at a minimum, wind, civil commotion (including riots), smoke, hail, and damage caused by aircraft, vehicle, or explosion.
Policies that limit or exclude from coverage (in whole or in part) windstorm, hurricane, hail damages, or any other perils that normally are included under an extended coverage endorsement are not acceptable.
Borrowers may not obtain property insurance policies that include such limitations or exclusions unless they are able to obtain a separate policy or endorsement from another commercial insurer that provides adequate coverage for the limited or excluded peril or from an insurance pool that the state has established to cover the limitations or exclusions.
Additional requirements apply to properties with solar panels that are leased from or owned by a third party under a power purchase agreement or other similar arrangement.
The insurance coverage should reflect one of the following:
. 100% of the insurable value of the improvements, as established by the property insurer; or
· 100% of the Total Estimate of Cost-New per the appraiser; or

The unpaid principal balance of the mortgage, as long as it at least equals the minimum amount-80% of the insurable value of the improvements-required to compensate for damage or loss on a replacement cost basis. If it does not, then coverage that does provide the minimum required amount must be obtained.

A Conflict-Of-Interest Transaction occurs when the borrower has an affiliation or relationship with the Mortgage Broker, Loan Officer, Real Estate Broker or Agent, or any other interested party to the transaction. Parameter: Cash-Out Refinance

Rule/Guideline: • Cash-Out Refinance is defined as a refinance that does not meet the definition of a rate/term refinance. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)

• LTV > 60% = $1,000,000 max cash in hand; LTV ≤ 60% = Unlimited max cash in hand. (PDF 2)

• If owned for less than 6 months, use the lesser of purchase price plus documented improvements or appraised value; if more than 6 months, use appraised value. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)

  - The borrower acquired the property through an inheritance or was legally awarded the property through divorce, separation, or dissolution of a domestic partnership. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)

• Properties classified as rural must meet specific conditions: classified as rural by the appraiser, two of the three comparable properties more than 5 miles away, and less than 25% of the surrounding area developed. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Rural properties are permitted under Primary Residence occupancy with a maximum LTV/CLTV of 75% and no cash-out to the borrower (purchase and rate & term only). (PDF 3)
• Rural properties are permitted under Second Home occupancy with a 5% deduction to LTV/CLTV from the applicable program matrix, and the borrower cannot receive any cash out (purchase and rate & term only). (PDF 3)
• Rural properties are not permitted under Investment occupancy. (PDF 3)
• Vacant land or land development properties are ineligible. (PDF 3)
• Personal property transferred through a property sale must have zero transfer value. (PDF 2)
• Escrow holdbacks are not allowed; repairs must be completed prior to loan purchase. (PDF 2)
• NA for specific land value requirements. (PDF 1, PDF 3)

Parameter: Condo - Warrantable / Established Condos
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Ownership must be fee simple or leasehold. Acceptable forms of vesting include individuals, joint tenants, tenants in common, and inter vivos revocable trust. Land trusts, blind trusts, and IRAs are not eligible forms of vesting. (PDF 1)
• The condominium project must meet all eligibility requirements for sale as required by Fannie Mae. Fannie Mae eligible projects are allowed. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Ineligible projects include condominium hotels, timeshares, new condo conversions completed less than 2 years, houseboat projects, manufactured home projects, assisted living facilities, multi-family units with single deed ownership, projects with more than 50% non-residential space, and projects with adverse environmental issues. Projects with names including 'hotel,' 'motel,' 'resort,' or 'lodge' are also ineligible. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Project must comply with local jurisdiction, state, and all other applicable laws and regulations. (PDF 1)
• Project must meet all FNMA insurance requirements for property, liability, and fidelity coverage. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Limited Review Eligible Transactions for attached units in established condo projects outside Florida: Principal Residence - 85% LTV/CLTV, Second Home - 75% LTV/CLTV, Investment Property - 75% LTV/CLTV. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Limited Review Eligible Transactions for Florida attached units in established condo projects: Principal Residence - 75% LTV/CLTV, Second Home - 70% LTV/CLTV, Investment Property - 70% LTV/CLTV. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Non-warrantable condominium projects allow only one non-warrantable factor per project. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Change Home Mortgage will not finance more than 20% of the units in any one project. (PDF 1)
• Investor concentration in any project is allowed up to 60%. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Max DTI is 43%. (PDF 1)
• Min FICO is 680. (PDF 1)
• Max LTV is program-specific. (PDF 1)
• Commercial space must be ≤ 50% and typical for the market. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• New projects must be complete with at least 50% of units sold or under contract. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• No more than 20% of units may be 60 days or more past due on HOA dues. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Annual budget must allocate a minimum of 5% for replacement reserves. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Pending litigation is considered case by case, but not allowed if it involves structural items or impacts marketability or safety. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Single entity ownership is allowed up to 25%. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Required project documents include a Condo Questionnaire, current annual HOA/Project Budget, current Balance Sheet, evidence of Project Insurance, and project legal documents as required by the project type. (PDF 3)
• The project must not be subject to the rules and regulations of the U.S. Securities Exchange Commission. (PDF 3)
• Projects not well managed or in poor physical or financial condition are ineligible. (PDF 3)
• Confirmation is needed that project documents do not give a unit owner or any other party priority over the rights of the 1st mortgagee. (PDF 3)

Parameter: Condo - Limited Review
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Fannie Mae eligible projects are allowed, and the review process should follow Fannie Mae requirements where applicable (PDF 1, PDF 3).
• Limited Review is applicable for attached units in established condo projects (PDF 1).
• Maximum LTV/CLTV and HCLTV ratios for projects outside Florida: Principal Residence - 85%, Second Home - 75%, Investment Property - 75% (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Maximum LTV/CLTV and HCLTV ratios for Florida attached units: Principal Residence - 75%, Second Home - 70%, Investment Property - 70% (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Non-warrantable condominium projects require a full review (PDF 1).
• Commercial space must be typical for the market and not negatively impact marketability, with a maximum of 50% commercial space (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• No more than 20% of total units may be 60 days or more past due on HOA dues (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Annual budget must allocate a minimum of 5% for replacement reserves (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Investor concentration in any project is allowed up to 60% (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Single entity ownership is allowed up to 25% (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Pending litigation is not allowed if it involves structural issues or impacts marketability or safety (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Change Home Mortgage will not finance more than 20% of the units in any one project (PDF 1).
• Stacking of risk is not allowed; only one non-warrantable factor per project is allowed (PDF 1).
• Developer may control the HOA if the Master Agreement provides for homeowners to take control upon a predetermined percentage of unit sales or within a defined time period (PDF 2).
• Project or subject's legal phase must be complete, and all common elements must be 100% completed (PDF 2).
• At least 50% of the units must be sold or under a bona-fide contract (PDF 2).
• Max DTI is 43% (PDF 1).
• Min FICO is 680 (PDF 1).
• Max LTV is based on applicable program matrices (PDF 1).

Parameter: Condos Non-Warrantable
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Only one non-warrantable factor per project is allowed. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Change Home Mortgage will not finance more than 20% of the units in any one project. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Investor concentration in any project is allowed up to 60%. Higher percentages may be considered for investment property transactions with a history of high rental units. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• A full review of the project is required. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Required documents include:
  - Change Lending HOA Questionnaire (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
  - Master property insurance, liability insurance, and flood insurance if applicable (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
  - HOA budget (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
  - Current balance sheet (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
  - CC&Rs and Bylaws (for new construction and conversion only) (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
  - Litigation documents, if applicable (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
  - Ground lease, if applicable (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Max Debt-to-Income (DTI) ratio: 43% (PDF 1, PDF 3); 55% (PDF 2)
• Min FICO score: 680 (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Max Loan-to-Value (LTV): Refer to applicable program matrices for LTV availability (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Commercial space must be ≤ 50% and typical for market with no negative impact on marketability. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• No more than 20% of total units in the project may be 60 days or more past due on HOA dues. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Annual budget must specify a minimum of 5% allocation of replacement reserves. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Single entity ownership up to 25%. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Pending litigation considered case by case; not allowed if involving structural items or safety concerns. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• New projects must have all common elements 100% completed, and at least 50% of units sold or under contract. (PDF 3)

Parameter: Condotels
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Min FICO: 680 (PDF 1)
• Max LTV: Refer to applicable program matrices for LTV availability (PDF 1)
• Subject property unit must be 100% residential (PDF 1)
• Project/building commercial percentage must be ≤ 50% (PDF 1)
• Commercial space must be typical for market and have no negative impact on marketability (PDF 1)
• No more than 20% of the total units in the project may be 60 days or more past due on HOA dues (PDF 1)
• Developer may control the HOA if the Master Agreement provides for homeowner control upon a predetermined percentage of unit sales or within a defined time period (PDF 1)
• Annual budget must specify a minimum of 5% allocation of replacement reserves (PDF 1)
• Investor concentration in project up to 60%; higher percentages may be considered with an established history of high rental units (PDF 1)
• Single entity ownership up to 25% (PDF 1)
• Pending litigation considered case by case; not allowed if it involves structural items or impacts marketability or safety (PDF 1)
• Projects subject to U.S. Securities Exchange Commission rules are ineligible (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Projects managed and operated as a hotel or motel are ineligible (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Projects with names including 'hotel,' 'motel,' 'resort,' or 'lodge' are ineligible (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Projects offering rentals on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis are ineligible (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Hotel or motel conversions are ineligible (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Condotels are considered ineligible projects (PDF 2)
• A Condotel is defined as a condominium project where any unit owner or the homeowners' association is a party to a revenue-sharing agreement with either the developer or another third-party entity (PDF 2)
• Resort type projects are ineligible (PDF 3)
• Timeshare or projects restricting owner's ability to occupy the unit are ineligible (PDF 3)
• New condo conversion completed less than 2 years is ineligible (PDF 3)
• Projects with fragmented or segmented ownership are ineligible (PDF 3)
• Ownership limited to a specific period on a recurring basis, i.e., Timeshare, is ineligible (PDF 3)
• Projects requiring private transfer fees not benefiting the association are ineligible (PDF 3)
• Projects in litigation, arbitration, mediation, or other disputes regarding safety, soundness, or habitability are ineligible (PDF 3)
• Projects with adverse environmental issues involving safety, soundness, or habitability are ineligible (PDF 3)
• Projects not well managed or in poor physical or financial condition are ineligible (PDF 3)
• Projects with excessive special assessments, low reserves, neglected repairs are ineligible (PDF 3)

Parameter: Assets - Business Assets
Category: Assets - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Business funds may be used for down payment, closing costs, and calculating reserves. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• The borrower must be listed as an owner of the business account. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• The account needs to be verified per the guidelines or requirements in the guide. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Business funds used to qualify are calculated based on the borrower's percentage of ownership in the company. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• If a borrower owns 25% of the business, only 25% of the available balance of the account would be allowed to qualify. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Ownership of the asset must be verified. (PDF 3)
• An independent valuation of the asset is required. (PDF 3)
• Ownership transfer of the asset and borrower's receipt of sale proceeds is required. (PDF 3)
• Assets held in foreign accounts are acceptable if they are seasoned for thirty (30) days with one-month most recent bank statement. (PDF 3)
• A currency calculation must be provided for foreign assets. (PDF 3)
• Assets from countries under OFAC sanctions are not permitted. (PDF 3)

Parameter: Assets - Eligibility, Sourcing & Verification
Category: Assets - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Bitcoin or other forms of cryptocurrency are permitted for funds to close and reserves if converted to cash; no seasoning required upon liquidation (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Cryptocurrency must be converted to cash and seasoned for 120 days to be used as qualifying assets (PDF 1).
• Verification of liquidated funds is required if needed to close (PDF 1).
• Large deposits in bank statements must be evaluated if exceeding 50% of total monthly qualifying income (PDF 1).
• For purchase transactions, documentation is required to verify large deposits from acceptable sources; unverified deposits must be excluded from qualifying assets (PDF 1).
• Proceeds from the sale of personal assets are acceptable for down payment, closing costs, and reserves with proper documentation of ownership, valuation, transfer, and receipt of proceeds (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Assets in foreign accounts are acceptable if seasoned for 30 days with the most recent bank statement; currency calculation is required (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Assets from countries under OFAC sanctions are not permitted (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Business funds can be used for down payment, closing costs, and reserves if the borrower is an account owner; verification is required and calculated based on the borrower's ownership percentage in the company (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Eligible assets include marketable securities, checking/savings, cash surrender value of life insurance/annuity, stocks, bonds, mutual funds, and vested retirement assets (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Ineligible assets include real estate refinance proceeds, privately traded or restricted/non-vested stocks, gift funds, assets producing income already included in income calculation, and certain trust assets (PDF 1, PDF 3).
• Account Statements should cover the most recent 30-day period, all pages are required (PDF 2).
• Verification of Deposit (VOD) should be dated within 30 days of closing date (PDF 2).
• Trust assets are eligible if held in a revocable trust or an irrevocable trust where the borrower is the beneficiary with immediate access (PDF 1).
• Qualifying income from assets is based on total eligible assets for depletion divided by 120 (PDF 3).

Parameter: Assets - Foreign Assets
Category: Assets - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Assets held in foreign accounts are acceptable and must be thirty (30) days seasoned with the one-month most recent bank statement. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• A currency calculation must be provided. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Assets from countries under OFAC sanctions are not permitted. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Foreign assets and businesses are not eligible for the personal or business bank statements income option. (PDF 2)
• Assets held in foreign accounts must be thirty (30) days seasoned in a U.S. bank account with one-month most recent bank statement. (PDF 2)
• Ownership of the asset, independent valuation of the asset, ownership transfer of the asset, and borrower's receipt of sale proceeds is required. (PDF 3)

Parameter: Assets - Ineligible Sources
Category: Assets - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Real Estate Refinance Proceeds are ineligible for asset depletion (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Privately traded or restricted/non-vested stocks are ineligible for asset depletion (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Gift funds are ineligible for asset depletion (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Any asset that produces income already included in the income calculation is ineligible for asset depletion (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Assets held in an irrevocable trust where the beneficiary of the trust is not the borrower are ineligible for asset depletion (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Assets held in a charitable giving trust, donor advised fund, or similar entity where the intended beneficiary is not the borrower are ineligible for asset depletion (PDF 1, PDF 2).
• Foreign assets are ineligible for asset depletion (PDF 1, PDF 3).

Parameter: Reserves
Category: Assets - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Reserves must be sourced and documented per guidelines. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Reserves are calculated off documented P&I payment plus taxes, insurance, and HOA fees, if applicable (PITIA). (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Reserves for a Step Payment transaction will be based on the fully amortized payment. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Reserves for an Interest Only transaction will be based on the initial Interest Only payment (ITIA). (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Proceeds from 1031 Exchange cannot be used to meet reserve requirements. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Cash out can be used as reserves. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Additional Financed REO requires a minimum reserve of six (6) months of the subject property's PITIA, increased to nine (9) months if the loan amount requires it. The reserve calculation is based on the subject property's PITIA, not the additional financed REO. (PDF 1)
• Any other characteristics of the transaction that require additional reserves are still required on top of the Additional Financed REO reserve requirement. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• Assets held in foreign accounts are acceptable and must be thirty (30) days seasoned with one-month most recent bank statement. A currency calculation must be provided. (PDF 3)
• Assets from countries under OFAC sanctions are not permitted. (PDF 3)
• Business funds may be used for down payment, closing costs, and for the purposes of calculating reserves, provided the borrower is listed as an owner of the business account and the account is verified per requirements in the Guide. Business funds used to qualify are calculated based on the borrower's percentage of ownership in the company. (PDF 3)

Parameter: DSCR Ratio Requirements
Category: Income - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • DSCR Ratio Requirements are not explicitly mentioned in PDF 1. (PDF 1)
• The DSCR factor is calculated using the most recent documented 12-month average. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Projected Monthly Revenue or Annual Estimated Income divided by 12 can be used as the qualifying rental income calculation. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Seller (on a purchase transaction) or Borrower (on a refinance transaction) must provide proof of receipt for the most recent 12-month period derived from an accredited 3rd party, subject to validation. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• AirDNA 'Rentalizer' occupancy factor must be at least 50% or greater to be eligible. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Qualifying rental income calculation is Annual Revenue divided by 12. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• CHM UW must re-pull the AirDNA 'Rentalizer' online to validate the information provided and notate the qualifying short-term rental calculation on the 1008. (PDF 2, PDF 3)

Parameter: Gross Rent Requirements
Category: Income - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Utilize 75% of the current lease income less the PITIA on a net basis for qualifying rental income. (PDF 1)
• Positive rents must be supported with proof of at least one current month's rent receipt. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Rental income cannot be used to qualify on a vacant unit. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Short-term rental income is permitted with proof of receipt for the most recent 12-month period documented by the property management company. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Qualifying rental income for short-term rentals is calculated based on the total rents received per the ledger provided divided by 12. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• For investment property transactions, use the lower of 75% of 1007 validating current market rents or 75% of the executed lease agreement in place for qualifying rental income. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• Short-term rents for current vacant properties apply to purchase transactions only unless the subject loan is a refinance transaction with documented recent vacancy due to a remodel or renovation. (PDF 1)
• The occupancy rate/factor must reflect at least 50% or greater to be eligible. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Projected Monthly Revenue or Annual Estimated Income divided by 12 can be used as the qualifying rental income calculation. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Seller or Borrower must provide proof of receipt for the most recent 12-month period derived from an accredited 3rd party, subject to validation. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• The DSCR factor is calculated using the most recent documented 12-month average. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• AirDNA 'Rentalizer' occupancy factor must be at least 50% or greater to be eligible. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• CHM UW must re-pull the AirDNA 'Rentalizer' online to validate the information and notate the qualifying short-term rental calculation on the 1008. (PDF 2)
• Rental income from an ADU attached to the subject property is eligible under specific conditions. (PDF 2)
• For refinance transactions, market rent for the ADU should be documented with a 1007 and a copy of the current lease agreement. (PDF 2)
• For purchase transactions, market rent for the ADU should be documented with a 1007 and a copy of the current lease agreement from the Seller. (PDF 2)
• Rental income must be qualified at 75% of the 1007 provided by the appraiser. (PDF 2)
• For short-term rents (29 days or less) on vacant properties, an appraiser must provide a Short Term Rental Income Analysis. (PDF 3)

Parameter: Interest-Only
Category: Income - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Interest-Only transactions are not eligible for cash-out refinance (PDF 1).
• Interest-Only loans are permitted up to a maximum LTV of 80% (PDF 2), but PDF 3 allows up to 85% LTV.
• Cash-out refinance is permitted up to 75% max LTV (PDF 3).
• First-time home buyers are not permitted to use Interest-Only (PDF 1).
• Interest-Only period is available for 10 years on all ARM & 30 Year Fixed rate products (PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Qualifying ratios are based on the fully amortized payment after the end of the interest-only period using the qualifying rate (PDF 2, PDF 3).
• Qualifying Rate for ARMs is the greater of the Fully Indexed Rate or Note Rate (PDF 2).
• Minimum FICO score required is 660 (PDF 3).
• Mortgage insurance is not required for Interest-Only transactions (PDF 2).
• Interest-Only loans are not eligible for cash-out transactions exceeding 80% LTV (PDF 2).

Parameter: Underwriting Method
Category: Income - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • All files are manually underwritten. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Loans are not assumable. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Loans closed within the first 5 days of the month may reflect an interest credit to the borrower. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• High-cost loans are not permitted. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Property insurance must protect against loss or damage from fire and other hazards covered by the standard extended coverage endorsement. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Insurance policies must not limit or exclude coverage for windstorm, hurricane, hail damages, or other perils unless a separate policy or endorsement provides adequate coverage. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Additional insurance requirements apply to properties with solar panels leased from or owned by a third party. (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Insurance coverage should reflect 100% of the insurable value of the improvements, 100% of the Total Estimate of Cost-New per the appraiser, or the unpaid principal balance of the mortgage, provided it equals at least 80% of the insurable value of the improvements. (PDF 2)
• Rent loss insurance covering a minimum of 6 months of the rental figure used to qualify is required for investment properties. (PDF 2)
• Prepayment penalties are allowed for investment property transactions when permitted by applicable laws and regulations, with specific conditions on the amount and timing of the penalty. (PDF 2)
• Higher-priced qualified mortgage loans with rebuttable presumption liability protection are prescribed by applicable regulation. (PDF 3)
• Each loan disclosing a qualifying income figure on the URLA must include a completed ATR Borrower Confirmation form, except for Business Purpose/Investment property transactions. (PDF 3)
• Verify the existence of the business within 30 days of the Note date. (PDF 1)
• Qualifying income is based on the lower of the 12-month P&L statement or the monthly income disclosed on the initial signed application (URLA). (PDF 1)
• When analyzing the P&L Statement, depreciation, depletion, amortization, and casualty loss may be added back to the applicant's income calculation. (PDF 1)
• Rental income calculations vary based on whether the rental property is the subject property or not. (PDF 1)
• For investment property transactions, rental income can be utilized to qualify from the subject property. (PDF 1)
• Short-term rental income is permitted with proof of receipt for the most recent 12-month period. (PDF 1)
• Supplemental income sources are limited to social security, pension, alimony, child support, asset distribution/utilization, and second job income. (PDF 1)
• Full documentation from a co-borrower who is not self-employed may be used to supplement qualifying income. (PDF 1)
• Credit file must contain documentation that the CPA/CTEC/PTIN license is verified and active. (PDF 1)

Parameter: Age of Loan Documentation
Category: Documentation - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Most recent 12-month P&L is required, and the P&L end date cannot exceed more than sixty (60) days old prior to the Note date. (PDF 1)
• All P&L statements must be completed by an independent CPA/EA/PTIN/CTEC, who must attest to preparing the borrower's most recent filed tax returns and confirm they are not related to or associated with the borrower or their business. (PDF 1)
• If the preparer did not file the most recent tax returns on behalf of the borrower, three (3) months of current bank statements are required to support the qualifying income within a 20% variance. (PDF 1)
• The credit file must contain documentation verifying that the CPA/CTEC/PTIN license is active. (PDF 1)
• Borrower narrative on the nature of the business is required. (PDF 1)
• An internet search of the business is required, and documentation must be included in the credit file to support the existence of the business. (PDF 1)
• Documentation in the file must be consistent with the information on the loan application. (PDF 1)
• The existence of the business must be verified within 30 days of the Note date, ensuring the business is active through one of the following: a letter from the business tax professional certifying at least 24 months of self-employment in the same business, validation from a regulatory agency or licensing bureau, or a phone listing and/or business address using directory assistance/internet search. (PDF 1)
• Age of loan documentation must adhere to FNMA standard guidelines. (PDF 2, PDF 3)

Parameter: Appraisal Requirements
Category: Documentation - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Full Interior/Exterior appraisal required using Fannie Mae/Freddie Mac Forms 1004/70, 1025/72, 1073/465, or 2090. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Licensed appraiser must perform an interior inspection for the appraisal report. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Appraisal should be dated no more than 120 days prior to the Note Date; a new appraisal is required after 120 days. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• A Desk Review or Second appraisal is required on every transaction. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Investment Property transactions require a Form 1007, 216, or 1025 (for 2-4 units) to determine current market rents if rental income is used to qualify. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• A Second Appraisal is required if the loan amount exceeds $2,000,000, the transaction is a flip, or as required under the Appraisal Review Products section. Additionally, it may be required at Underwriter Discretion. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Second appraisal must be from a different appraiser than the first appraisal. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• An appraisal review product is required on every appraisal for the transaction, which can be an enhanced desk review or a field review/second appraisal from a Change Home Mortgage approved AMC. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• If the Appraisal Review Product reflects a value more than 10% below the appraised value or cannot provide a validation, a field review or second appraisal is required from a different appraisal company and appraiser than the original appraisal. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• On transactions where the difference in appraised value is less than 10%, the acceptability of the appraisal is subject to UW Management review and discretion. (PDF 1, PDF 3)
• The final appraised value is based on the lowest reported value amongst all appraisal documents/reviews. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Minimum square footage requirements: Single Family Residence - 700 sq ft, Condominiums - 400 sq ft, 2-4 units - 250 sq ft per unit. (PDF 2, PDF 3)

Parameter: Escrow Holdbacks
Category: Escrows / Insurance - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Escrow holdbacks are not allowed for loans under the guidelines outlined in the documents. (PDF 1)
• Any repair or maintenance required by the appraiser must be completed prior to loan purchase. (PDF 1)
• No additional information or conflicting guidelines regarding escrow holdbacks are provided in PDF 2 and PDF 3.

Parameter: Escrow Impounds / Flood Insurance
Category: Escrows / Insurance - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Property insurance must protect against loss or damage from fire and other hazards covered by the standard extended coverage endorsement. (Consistent across PDFs)
• Coverage must provide for claims to be settled on a replacement cost basis. (Consistent across PDFs)
• Extended coverage must include wind, civil commotion, smoke, hail, and damage caused by aircraft, vehicle, or explosion. (Consistent across PDFs)
• Policies that limit or exclude coverage for windstorm, hurricane, hail damages, or other perils normally included under an extended coverage endorsement are not acceptable. Borrowers may not obtain property insurance policies with such limitations or exclusions unless they obtain a separate policy or endorsement providing adequate coverage for the limited or excluded peril. (Consistent across PDFs)
• Insurance coverage must reflect one of the following: 100% of the insurable value of the improvements, 100% of the Total Estimate of Cost-New per the appraiser, or the unpaid principal balance of the mortgage, as long as it equals at least 80% of the insurable value of the improvements. (Consistent across PDFs)
• For insurance not addressed in this section, default to Fannie Mae requirements. (Consistent across PDFs)
• Additional requirements apply to properties with solar panels leased from or owned by a third party. (PDF 3)
• NA for specific requirements on escrow impounds. (PDF 1, PDF 2)
• NA for specific requirements on flood insurance. (Consistent across PDFs)

Parameter: Title Insurance Requirements
Category: Title / Legal - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Ownership must be fee simple or Leasehold. (PDF 1)
• Acceptable forms of vesting are Individuals, Joint tenants, Tenants in common, and Inter Vivos Revocable Trust. (PDF 1)
• Land trusts, Blind Trusts, and IRAs are not eligible forms of vesting. (PDF 1)
• For Investment Properties, Limited Liability Companies (LLC) are allowed with specific requirements: (PDF 1)
  - Maximum of 4 owners or members. (PDF 1)
  - All members must provide personal guarantees. (PDF 1)
  - Each member must complete a Form 1003 or similar credit application. (PDF 1)
  - Each member must receive notice of the loan and its terms prior to closing. (PDF 1)
  - Required documentation includes Entity Articles of Organization, Operating Agreement(s), Tax Identification Number, Certificate of Authorization, and Borrowing Certificate. (PDF 1)
• Leasehold estates must be documented via the Appraisal and insured by the lender's title policy. (PDF 1)
• Documentation must confirm Leaseholds meet all FNMA eligibility requirements. (PDF 1)
• No additional specific title insurance requirements were noted in PDFs 2 and 3.

Parameter: Loan Amounts
Category: Loan Structure - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Minimum Loan Amount: $50,000 (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Maximum Loan Amount: $3,500,000 (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Loan amounts over $2,000,000 require two appraisals and a Desk Review (PDF 2, PDF 3)
• Investment Properties loan amount capped at $2,000,000 max (PDF 2)
• Maximum LTV/CLTV: 90% / 90% (PDF 2)
• Properties in Declining Markets require a 5% reduction to max LTV/CLTV (PDF 3)
• Minimum FICO: 660 (PDF 2)
• Mortgage Insurance: Not required (PDF 2, PDF 3)

Rule/Guideline: • Prepayment penalties are applicable only for Investment Property transactions when permitted by applicable laws and regulations. (PDF 1, PDF 2, PDF 3)

1.0 COMPLIANCE AND REGULATORY
1.1 Ability To Repay (ATR)
All loans subject to the general ATR underwriting standards (12 C.F.R 1026.43(c)) require a creditor to make a reasonable, good-faith determination that the consumer has a reasonable ability to repay the loan prior to or at consummation. A reasonable, good-faith ATR evaluation must consider the following eight underwriting factors based on available information in the mortgage loan file using reliable third-party records:
. Income or assets used to repay the loan.
· Employment status.
· Monthly mortgage payment on the subject loan (fully indexed, fully amortizing).
· Monthly payments for any simultaneous loans secured by the subject property.
· Monthly payments for property taxes, hazard insurance, HOA fees, or ground rents.
· Debts (reported by a credit bureau or disclosed by the consumer), alimony, and child support obligations.
. Monthly DTI or residual income.
. Credit history.
1.2 Exceptions & Items Not Addressed in this Guide
Unless otherwise stated, Fannie Mae definitions, required documentation and underwriting guidelines should be followed. Additionally, while these Underwriting Guidelines are intended to be comprehensive, they may not encompass all specific loan or borrower scenarios.
In the event the underwriter determines an exception is warranted, the exception will be considered case by case, with compensating factors such as the below:
. The borrower's residential payment history for 24 months is 0x30
· 6 months reserves greater than the program required
· FICO points greater than 20 points over required
· DTI >10% below the program requirements or DSCR >1.15
· LTV 10% below the maximum allowed
. The borrower has additional income that is not used to qualify
All exceptions will be reviewed by the underwriting manager.
1.3 Fair Lending
FCM strictly complies with all applicable federal, state, and local requirements related to fair lending, including the Equal Credit Opportunity Act and the Fair Housing Act (together, the "Fair Lending Requirements"). Accordingly, in connection with its decision to purchase loans, FCM will not discriminate on any prohibited basis. FCM will also not knowingly purchase loans from Sellers engaged in practices that violate Fair Lending Requirements. To the extent a Seller is found to be engaging in practices that may violate Fair Lending Requirements.
1.4 Home Mortgage Disclosure ACT (HMDA)
FCM will comply with the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA), including without limitation all data collection, recordkeeping, and reporting requirements.
1.5 Higher Priced Mortgage Loan (HPML)

All loans must comply with TRID rules except for loans originated solely for business purposes, as defined in 12 CFR 1026.3(a)(1)of Regulation Z.
As used in this Guide, a "Business Purpose Loan" means a loan:
· Single Family Non-Owner Occupied: To acquire, improve or maintain rental property (regardless of the number of housing units) that is not owner-occupied. This includes, for example, a single-family house that will be rented to another person to live in. If the owner expects to occupy the property for more than 14 days during the coming year, the property cannot be considered non-owner-occupied, and this special rule will not apply. For example, a beach house that the owner will occupy for a month in the coming summer and rent out the rest of the year is owner occupied and is not Business Purpose Loan.
. Loans meeting this definition of "Business Purpose" are not subject to ability to repay and TRID disclosure requirements; borrower(s) must affirm the purpose of the loan by executing a Business Purpose and Occupancy Affidavit or a similar form. If a Business Purpose disclosure is not in the file, then the merits of the file must indicate that the loan meets the definition of a Business Purpose loan.
· Special rules also apply to Business Purpose loans where the borrower is taking cash out of the transaction. In such situations, the cash being taken out must also be used for a Business Purpose and not for personal or consumer use. This includes, for example, using the cash-out of the transaction to improve or maintain other rental properties owned by a borrower. An example of an impermissible use would include using the cash-out of transaction to pay for college tuition or personal debt (i.e., for a non-business purpose).

8.19 Sales Comparison Approach
Each appraisal must contain an estimate of market value, defined as:
. The most probable price a property should bring in a competitive and open market, under all conditions requisite to a fair sale, with both buyer and seller acting prudently, knowledgeably, and without undue pressure.
Assumptions of this definition include:
· Both buyer and seller are typically motivated.
· Each party is well-informed and acting in their best interest.
· The property has been adequately exposed to the open market.
· Sale terms reflect cash or equivalent financing.
. The price is unaffected by special concessions or incentives.
8.20 Minimum Comparable Sales Requirements
· A minimum of three (3) closed comparable sales must be provided.
· Additional comparable sales may be included to support the appraiser's opinion of value.

· Contract offerings and current listings may be used as supplemental data, when appropriate.
8.21 Comparable Selection Criteria
Comparables used in the sales comparison approach should:
· Be located within one (1) mile of the subject property.
· Be closed within the last 12 months.
· Be similar to the subject property in terms of:

- Size
- Design and features
- Amenities
· Reflect reasonable and well-supported adjustments, including:
- Individual line item adjustments
- Gross and net adjustments
· Have a sales price within a reasonable range of the subject's value.
· Include at least three recently closed sales as the primary basis of comparison.
Exceptions
When suitable comparables do not meet the above criteria, the appraiser must:
· Clearly explain and justify the use of alternative comparables.
· Provide market support for the adjustments and the resulting opinion of value.

• It is treated as cash-out for pricing and eligibility; cash-in-hand limits do not apply. (PDF 4)
• The original purchase must be an arm's-length transaction. (PDF 4)
• A documented source of funds used to purchase the property is required, such as bank statements, personal loans, or HELOC on another property. (PDF 4)
• LTV/CLTV is based on the lesser of the current appraised value or the purchase price plus documented improvements. (PDF 4)
• A preliminary title report must show no existing liens. (PDF 4)
• The new loan amount may not exceed the actual documented amount of the borrower's initial investment, subject to program maximum LTV/CLTV limits for cash-out transactions. (PDF 4)
• The property must be taken off the market one month prior to application. (PDF 4)
• Refer to the Sharp Advantage Program Matrix for specific guidelines regarding properties that are or have been listed for sale. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Business Purpose Loans
Category: Eligible Transactions - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Loan must be for business purposes only, not for personal, family, or household use. (PDF 4)
• Property must be operated as rental units for profit. (PDF 4)
• Borrower must not occupy the property at any time while the loan is outstanding. (PDF 4)
• Borrower must execute a Business Purpose & Occupancy Affidavit. (PDF 4)
• Loan is secured by non-owner-occupied real property. (PDF 4)
• Loan may not be subject to certain federal and state consumer protection laws. (PDF 4)
• False statements or misrepresentations may result in civil and criminal penalties. (PDF 4)
• Entity ownership or title vesting in LLC, Partnership, or Corporation is acceptable. (PDF 4)
• Borrower must be at least 25% or majority shareholder. (PDF 4)
• Entity limited to a maximum of 4 owners. (PDF 4)
• Personal Guaranties required from all borrowers and any individual/member with 50% or more ownership. (PDF 4)
• Entity must be domiciled in a US State. (PDF 4)
• Rent Loss Insurance required, covering at least 6 months PITIA. (PDF 4)
• Flip transactions are not permitted. (PDF 4)
• First-time homebuyers are not eligible. (PDF 4)
• Power of Attorney (POA) is not permitted. (PDF 4)
• Entity documents required: Articles of Organization, Certificate of Good Standing, EIN Verification, Certificate of Authorization, and Corporate documents listing owners and ownership percentage. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Credit Report
Category: Credit / Housing - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • A minimum of 12 months must have elapsed on any payment plan. (PDF 4)
• On-time payment history is required for the most recent 12 months. (PDF 4)
• A letter from the CCCS administrator authorizing new mortgage financing must be provided. (PDF 4)
• All open judgments, wage garnishments, and outstanding liens must be paid in full prior to or at loan closing. (PDF 4)
• Delinquent accounts solely assigned to an ex-spouse may be excluded if documentation shows the accounts belong to the ex-spouse. (PDF 4)
• All housing events must be fully resolved prior to closing with no outstanding deficiency balance. (PDF 4)
• A 12-month mortgage history is required for all financed properties. (PDF 4)
• Payments not shown on the credit report must be verified via VOR/VOM from an institutional source. (PDF 4)
• All mortgage/rent accounts must be current at closing. (PDF 4)
• Properties held in the name of an LLC must have the mortgage history documented. (PDF 4)
• Borrowers with no housing history or less than 12 months verified are subject to restrictions. (PDF 4)
• Consumer debts must be no more than 30 days past due at the time of closing. (PDF 4)
• Authorized user accounts are not considered in the borrower's debt-to-income ratio unless the borrower is making payments. (PDF 4)
• NA for any other specific credit report requirements. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Credit/Housing Event Seasoning
Category: Credit / Housing - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Seasoning is measured from the completion date of the event to the application date. (PDF 4)
• All housing events must be fully resolved prior to closing, with no outstanding deficiency balance. (PDF 4)
• For 120+ Day Mortgage Delinquency, seasoning begins from the date the mortgage was brought current. (PDF 4)
• For Bankruptcy (Property Surrendered in Chapter 7), use the bankruptcy discharge date for seasoning. Bankruptcy documentation must confirm the property was surrendered. (PDF 4)
• For Loan Modifications, seasoning begins from the modification execution date. Modifications are subject to Housing Event seasoning if they include forgiveness of principal or interest, principal curtailment, conversion of debt to a 'soft' subordinate lien, or reclassification of secured debt to unsecured. (PDF 4)
• Refer to the Sharp Advantage Program Matrix for additional seasoning requirements related to housing events. (PDF 4)
• No conflicting information was found across the PDFs, as PDFs 1, 2, and 3 did not contain relevant information.

Parameter: Collections / Charge-Offs / Judgments
Category: Credit / Housing - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • All open judgments, wage garnishments, and outstanding liens must be paid in full prior to or at loan closing. (PDF 4)
• Delinquent accounts solely assigned to an ex-spouse may be excluded if a divorce decree or separation agreement shows the accounts belong to the ex-spouse, and late payments occurred after the divorce/separation date. (PDF 4)
• Collection accounts may be excluded from cumulative totals if documentation assigns the debt to the ex-spouse. (PDF 4)
• There are no specific requirements on collections and charge-offs not related to ex-spouse situations provided in the documents. (PDF 4)
• No additional information or conflicting guidelines are provided in PDFs 1, 2, and 3, as they contain no relevant data on this parameter.

Parameter: Borrower Eligibility
Category: Borrower Eligibility - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Individuals on OFAC's SDN list are not eligible. All parties must be screened through exclusionary lists and cleared through OFAC's SDN list. (PDF 4)
• Borrowers/Guarantors from OFAC sanctioned countries are not eligible. (PDF 4)
• First-time homebuyers are not eligible for Sharp Advantage DSCR programs. (PDF 4)
• U.S. Citizens are eligible for financing. (PDF 4)
• Permanent Resident Aliens are eligible with acceptable documentation such as a valid Green Card or foreign passport with a valid I-551 stamp. (PDF 4)
• Non-Permanent Resident Aliens must have a valid Social Security Number, work authorization, a minimum 2-year credit history, and 2 years employment in the same line of work. (PDF 4)
• Acceptable visa classifications for Non-Permanent Resident Aliens include H-1B, L-1A, O-1A, and TN-NAFTA. (PDF 4)
• Borrowers from countries under OFAC sanctions or citizens of Venezuela, Russia, Belarus, China, Iran, North Korea, Cuba, and Syria are ineligible. (PDF 4)
• Florida SB 264 and Texas SB 17 restrict eligibility for citizens of certain countries. (PDF 4)
• Maximum exposure is 10 loans per borrower or total financing of $5.5 million, whichever is less. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Borrower – Experienced
Category: Borrower Eligibility - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Borrowers must have been receiving 1099 income for a minimum of 1 year. (PDF 4)
• The borrower must be in the same line of work for no less than 2 years. (PDF 4)
• Eligible borrowers must be self-employed for a minimum of 2 years. (PDF 4)
• Business ownership requires a minimum of 25% ownership interest in the company. (PDF 4)
• Business existence must be verified with a minimum of 1 year using a business license, letter from a third-party, or Secretary of State filing. (PDF 4)
• Profit and Loss statement must cover the most recent 12 months and be prepared by a third-party Tax Professional. (PDF 4)
• Business bank statements must show total deposits within 35% of gross receipts on the Profit and Loss Statement. (PDF 4)
• Qualifying income is calculated as net income from the P&L, less the percent of ownership, divided by 12 months. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Borrower – DACA / ITIN
Category: Borrower Eligibility - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Individuals identified on OFAC's SDN list are not eligible. (PDF 4)
• Borrowers/Guarantors from OFAC sanctioned countries are not eligible. (PDF 4)
• Borrowers must have a valid Social Security Number. (PDF 4)
• Authorization to work in the U.S. with a demonstrated likelihood of employment continuation for at least 3 years is required. (PDF 4)
• A minimum 2-year credit history is required. (PDF 4)
• 2 years employment in the same line of work and 2 years housing history (U.S. or abroad) is required. (PDF 4)
• Borrowers who have been offered and sponsored for employment in the U.S. under an H1-B1 Visa must provide documentation of sponsorship and evidence of first paycheck. (PDF 4)
• Borrowers who cannot provide evidence of lawful U.S. residency are not eligible for financing. (PDF 4)
• NA for specific DACA/ITIN requirements. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Entity Vesting - Signature Requirements
Category: Entity Vesting - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Entity must be created for the purposes of owning and managing real estate. (PDF 4)
• Entity is limited to a maximum of 4 owners (members, partners, or shareholders). (PDF 4)
• Each Entity owner must apply as the borrower and complete a 1003 as an individual applicant. (PDF 4)
• Entity must be domiciled in a US State. (PDF 4)
• Personal Guaranties are required from all borrowers on the loan along with any individual/member with 50% or more ownership in the Entity. (PDF 4)
• Borrower(s) must have the authority to execute loan documents on behalf of the entity. (PDF 4)
• Loan Application (1003) must be completed and signed by each borrower. (PDF 4)
• Personal Guaranty must be completed and signed by each borrower. (PDF 4)
• Personal Guaranty is not required when all members of the entity sign the Note personally AND for the entity and sign the mortgage as a member of the entity. (PDF 4)
• If the above is not true, Personal Guaranty is required and must be executed by all borrowers/guarantors. (PDF 4)
• The guaranty for any non-borrower with 50% or greater ownership in the entity may be executed prior to closing, any terms referenced on the guaranty must reference the final terms on the loan. (PDF 4)
• Spousal Consent to Pledge in community property states (AK, AZ, ID, LA, NM, TX, WA, WI). (PDF 4)
• Disclosures (GFE/LE, TIL, Notice of Intent to Proceed, Servicing Disclosure, etc.) must be completed and signed by each individual borrower. (PDF 4)
• CD or HUD 1 must be completed and signed by the borrower(s). (PDF 4)
• Other Closing Documents (Final TIL, Business Purpose and Occupancy Affidavit, etc.) must be completed by the Borrower(s). (PDF 4)
• Note must be completed by the guarantor(s) when accompanied by a Personal Guaranty OR by all members of the Entity both individually and as members when a Personal Guaranty is not executed. (PDF 4)
• Deed of Trust/Mortgage, and all attached Riders must be completed by borrower(s). (PDF 4)
• Power of Attorney (POA) is not permitted. (PDF 4)
• Entity Articles of Organization or Partnership. (PDF 4)
• Certificate of Good Standing or equivalent. (PDF 4)
• Employer Identification Number (EIN) Verification Form. (PDF 4)
• Certificate of Authorization for the person executing all documents on behalf of the entity. (PDF 4)
• Corporate documents that contain a list of owners, title, and ownership percentage, e.g., organization structure. (PDF 4)
• Corporation Specific Documents: Filed Certificate/Articles of Incorporation (and all amendments), By-Laws (and all amendments). (PDF 4)

Parameter: Vesting & Ownership
Category: Entity Vesting - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Entity vesting is permitted on investment properties only. (PDF 4)
• Transaction type must be business-purpose, investment property only. (PDF 4)
• Entity must be formed in a U.S. state. (PDF 4)
• Ownership is limited to no more than four members or owners. (PDF 4)
• Personal guaranty is required from members with ≥ 25% ownership; full recourse. (PDF 4)
• At least one guarantor must have authority to sign on behalf of the entity. (PDF 4)
• Each guarantor must complete a FNMA 1003 application, indicating guarantor status. (PDF 4)
• Underwriting and pricing are based on guarantors' credit scores and creditworthiness. (PDF 4)
• Required documentation varies by entity type (LLC, Corporation, Partnership). (PDF 4)
• Entity must be created for the purposes of owning and managing real estate. (PDF 4)
• Entity must be domiciled in a US State. (PDF 4)
• Personal guaranties are required from all borrowers on the loan and any individual/member with 50% or more ownership in the entity. (PDF 4)
• Borrower(s) must have the authority to execute loan documents on behalf of the entity. (PDF 4)
• Entity documents required include Articles of Organization, Certificate of Good Standing, EIN Verification Form, and Certificate of Authorization. (PDF 4)
• Corporation-specific documents include Filed Certificate/Articles of Incorporation and By-Laws. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Accessory Dwelling Units
Category: Collateral - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • An Accessory Dwelling Unit (ADU) is defined as an additional living space independent of the primary unit, featuring a separate kitchen, bathroom, and entrance. (PDF 4)
• Property classification is influenced by factors such as separate tax classification, zoning, utilities, postal address, and rental use. (PDF 4)
• The property must be taxed as a one-unit property with a single ADU; multiple ADUs are not allowed. (PDF 4)
• The appraisal must demonstrate that the improvements are typical for the market, supported by at least one comparable property with similar use. (PDF 4)
• The appraisal must confirm legal zoning compliance, although a permit is not required. (PDF 4)
• The appraiser must describe the ADU and analyze its impact on value and marketability. (PDF 4)
• For owner-occupied or second home purchases, ADU income cannot be used for qualification. (PDF 4)
• For non-owner-occupied purchases, use the lower of market rent (Form 1007) or actual rent for qualification. (PDF 4)
• For refinancing, FNMA Form 1007 is required to document market rent. (PDF 4)
• If using above market rent, a current lease and two months' rent receipts are required. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Property - Acreage and Land Value
Category: Collateral - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Acreage includes road frontage and subject property. (PDF 4)
• Property must not be agricultural or provide a source of income to the borrower. (PDF 4)
• Lot size and acreage must be typical for the area and like surrounding properties. (PDF 4)
• Property cannot be subject to idle acreage tax benefit, tax abatements, or other tax incentive programs. (PDF 4)
• Present use as per the appraisal must be the 'highest and best use' for the property. (PDF 4)
• Condition, quality, and use of outbuildings should be considered in determining the market value of the subject property when the appraiser clearly supports the adjustments with similar comparable information. (PDF 4)
• Refer to the Program Matrix for eligibility and LTV restrictions. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Declining Markets
Category: Collateral - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • If the appraiser indicates the subject property is located in a declining market, the appraisal must be reviewed by the underwriter for confirmation of market trends and valuation impact. (PDF 4)
• A valuation reduction may be applied at the underwriter's discretion to account for market risk. (PDF 4)
• Refer to the Program Matrix for specific LTV and eligibility adjustments applicable to properties in declining markets. (PDF 4)
• No relevant information on declining markets was found in PDFs 1, 2, and 3.

Parameter: Condo - Warrantable / Established Condos
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • At least 90% of the total units must be sold and conveyed to unit owners. (PDF 4)
• A minimum of 40% of units must be owner-occupied. (PDF 4)
• For investment property transactions only, at least 50% of the total units in the project must be conveyed to purchasers as a primary residence or second home. (PDF 4)
• All phases of the project must be complete. (PDF 4)
• The HOA must be under unit owner control; no developer or builder-controlled projects are permitted. (PDF 4)
• Appraisals for established projects with 100+ units may use comparable sales from within the project. (PDF 4)
• Model match units, if available, must be used in the appraisal. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Condo - Limited Review
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • All condominium projects must meet eligibility criteria, including complete common areas and amenities. (PDF 4)
• Each unit must have a full-size kitchen and at least one bedroom. (PDF 4)
• The project's sustainability, marketability, and financial stability must be supportable. (PDF 4)
• Condominium ownership must be common and market-acceptable in the project's area. (PDF 4)
• The project must comply with all applicable local and state laws, and the HOA must be incorporated in the state where the project is located. (PDF 4)
• The project must maintain adequate insurance coverage. (PDF 4)
• An environmental hazard assessment is required if due diligence identifies potential environmental concerns. (PDF 4)
• Projects with pending or threatened litigation related to safety, structural soundness, habitability, or functional use are generally ineligible. (PDF 4)
• The project must be located on a single contiguous parcel of land. (PDF 4)
• Project structures must be within reasonable proximity, and shared elements must be consistent with the project's nature. (PDF 4)
• A single borrower may not own more than 10% of the units in the same condominium development. (PDF 4)
• FCM exposure is limited to no more than 15% of the total units in any project. (PDF 4)
• No more than 15% of the total units may be 60 days or more past due on HOA dues. (PDF 4)
• No single entity may own more than 20% of total units in projects with more than 20 units. (PDF 4)
• No more than 35% of the total square footage may be used for commercial purposes. (PDF 4)
• The mortgagee may not be responsible for more than the greater of 6 months or the maximum amount permitted under applicable state law for delinquent HOA dues. (PDF 4)
• All project facilities must be owned by the unit owners or HOA. (PDF 4)
• At least 90% of the total units must be sold and conveyed to unit owners for established projects. (PDF 4)
• A minimum of 40% of units must be owner-occupied for established projects. (PDF 4)
• For investment property transactions, at least 50% of the total units must be conveyed to purchasers as a primary residence or second home. (PDF 4)
• All phases of the project must be complete. (PDF 4)
• The HOA must be under unit owner control for established projects. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Condos Non-Warrantable
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Minimum 60% of units sold or under bona fide contract. (PDF 4)
• No more than 35% of the total units in the project >60 days delinquent on HOA dues. (PDF 4)
• Up to 30% of units may be tenant occupied. (PDF 4)
• HOA Budget must include a dedicated line item allocation to replacement reserves of at least 10% of the budget. (PDF 4)
• Litigation involving structural issues, health and safety issues, or items impacting marketability is not accepted. (PDF 4)
• Newly converted projects must have the project or subject's legal phase complete, all common areas 100% complete, and a minimum of 50% of units sold or under contract. (PDF 4)
• HOA should be in control. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Condotels
Category: Condos / Property Type - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Condotels are condominium projects managed and operated as hotels or motels, with individual units privately owned. (PDF 4)
• Includes registration services and offers rental of units on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis. (PDF 4)
• Property must be located in a resort or metropolitan area. (PDF 4)
• Project must have obtained a hotel or resort rating from recognized rating providers. (PDF 4)
• All common elements in the project or legal phase must be 100% complete. (PDF 4)
• Homeowners must have control of the HOA. (PDF 4)
• Investor concentration within the project may be up to 100%. (PDF 4)
• Fractional ownership and timeshares are not permitted. (PDF 4)
• Mandatory rental pools or requirements to rent the unit are not allowed. (PDF 4)
• Occupancy restrictions or blackout dates that prevent year-round owner occupancy are not permitted. (PDF 4)
• Unit must be a minimum of 500 square feet. (PDF 4)
• Unit must have at least one separate bedroom. (PDF 4)
• Unit must have a fully functioning kitchen, including a stove/oven (cooktop-only configurations are not permitted). (PDF 4)
• Only investment properties are allowed. (PDF 4)
• At least 30% of the total units in the project or subject phase must be sold or under bona fide contract. (PDF 4)
• A single borrower may not own more than 30% of the total units in the condominium project. (PDF 4)
• Refer to the Sharp Advantage Program Matrix for specific LTV eligibility. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Reserves
Category: Assets - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Reserves are calculated as the number of months of housing expense (PITIA) a borrower can cover using eligible financial assets. (PDF 4)
• When multiple reserve requirements apply, use the highest single requirement, not a cumulative total. (PDF 4)
• Net proceeds from a cash-out refinance may be used to meet reserve requirements. (PDF 4)
• Interest Only loans: Reserves based on the Interest Only payment. (PDF 4)
• ARMs: Reserves based on initial PITIA, not the qualifying payment. (PDF 4)
• 1031 Exchange proceeds are not eligible for reserves. (PDF 4)
• Gift funds are not permitted for reserves. (PDF 4)
• Vested funds from IRAs, SEP, Keogh, and 401(k) accounts are acceptable for reserves. (PDF 4)
• Cryptocurrency must be liquidated and held in a U.S. account for a minimum of 30 days prior to the Note date to be used for reserves. (PDF 4)
• Vested stocks, government bonds, and mutual funds are acceptable for reserves, provided the asset value and borrower ownership are verified. (PDF 4)
• Liquidation of stocks, bonds, and mutual funds is not required for reserves. (PDF 4)
• Funds from a borrower's trust account may be used for reserves if the borrower has immediate access to the funds. (PDF 4)
• Funds held solely in the name of a non-borrowing spouse are not eligible for reserve requirements. (PDF 4)
• Vested stock options are not eligible for reserves. (PDF 4)
• NA for any other specific requirements, limits, and conditions not explicitly mentioned. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Gross Rent Requirements

Parameter: Appraisal Requirements
Category: Documentation - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Appraisal review documentation is required for all loan files unless a second appraisal is obtained. (PDF 4)
• Eligible Appraisal Review Products: Collateral Underwriter® (CU®) with a CU Score of 2.5 or less. (PDF 4)
• If CU Score exceeds 2.5, an Enhanced Desk Review, Field Review, or Second Appraisal is required. (PDF 4)
• If the enhanced desk review reflects a value variance more than 10% below the original appraised value or is indeterminate, a field review or second appraisal is required. (PDF 4)
• A second appraisal is required for loans with a loan amount greater than $2,000,000. (PDF 4)
• Two full interior/exterior appraisals must be obtained, and the lower value is used for LTV calculation. (PDF 4)
• Each appraisal must be completed by different appraisers and companies. (PDF 4)
• Appraisers must be state-licensed or certified, with geographic competency and experience with the property type. (PDF 4)
• Unlicensed appraisers may contribute under supervision, with the licensed appraiser accepting full responsibility. (PDF 4)
• Appraisals must be completed within 4 months and not more than 12 months prior to the Note date. If older than 4 months, an appraisal update is required. (PDF 4)
• Appraisals must not include prohibited basis references such as race or ethnicity. (PDF 4)
• A minimum of three closed comparable sales must be provided, located within one mile and closed within the last 12 months. (PDF 4)
• Properties must meet minimum square footage requirements: 700 sq. ft. for single-family, 500 sq. ft. for condominiums, and 400 sq. ft. per unit for 2-4 unit properties. (PDF 4)
• Properties with evidence of sinkhole activity are ineligible. (PDF 4)
• Hazard insurance and flood insurance are required under specific conditions. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Escrow Impounds / Flood Insurance
Category: Escrows / Insurance - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Escrow account must be established for payment of property taxes and mortgage-related insurance on Higher Priced Mortgage Loans as defined by 12 CFR 1026.35. (PDF 4)
• Flood insurance must always be escrowed. (PDF 4)
• Escrow funds/impound accounts may be waived for taxes and hazard insurance on non-HPML transaction loans if:
  - The representative credit score is greater than 700. (PDF 4)
  - At least twelve months reserves are documented. (PDF 4)
  - The LTV/CLTV of the loan does not exceed 80%. (PDF 4)
• Flood insurance is required for properties located in a Special Flood Hazard Area (SFHA) as designated by FEMA. (PDF 4)
• Properties must be in a participating NFIP community to be eligible for financing. (PDF 4)
• Maximum deductible for standard properties is $10,000; for PUD/Condo projects, it is $25,000. (PDF 4)
• A Flood Certificate from FEMA is required to determine flood zone status. (PDF 4)
• Flood insurance requirements may be waived if improvements are not located in the SFHA or if a FEMA Letter of Map Amendment (LOMA) or Letter of Map Revision (LOMR) is provided. (PDF 4)
• Minimum flood insurance coverage must be the lesser of 100% of the replacement cost of the improvements, $250,000, or the unpaid principal balance of the mortgage. (PDF 4)
• NA for escrows for work completion. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Title Insurance Requirements
Category: Title / Legal - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Title insurer must be authorized and licensed in the property's state. (PDF 4)
• Insurer must meet lender's approval standards, including acceptable insurance rating, financial strength, adequate reserves, and satisfactory claim resolution history. (PDF 4)
• Must conform to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac title underwriting insurer requirements. (PDF 4)
• Iowa Title Guaranty is acceptable for properties in Iowa. (PDF 4)
• Gap coverage must document first lien position post-closing via final title policy, bring-down search, or gap coverage. (PDF 4)
• All borrower names must appear on the title commitment. (PDF 4)
• Seller's name must match across purchase agreement and chain of title. (PDF 4)
• Coverage must be no less than the original principal loan amount. (PDF 4)
• Title policy must name the lender and include 'Its successors and assigns as their interest may appear.' (PDF 4)
• Preliminary title report must be dated within 120 days of closing. (PDF 4)
• All title requirements must be satisfied prior to closing. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Power of Attorney
Category: Title / Legal - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Use of a Limited Power of Attorney (POA) is permitted under specific conditions. (PDF 4)
• The POA must be limited to the subject transaction and include a clearly defined expiration date. (PDF 4)
• Must be submitted for review and approval to the Underwriting Manager. (PDF 4)
• The borrower must personally sign the initial Uniform Residential Loan Application (FNMA Form 1003). (PDF 4)
• POA is not permitted for cash-out refinance transactions. (PDF 4)
• POA may not be used to execute documents on behalf of a trust or business entity. (PDF 4)

Parameter: Prepayment Penalties
Category: Loan Structure - Feature Eligibility
Rule/Guideline: • Prepayment penalties are allowed on Investment Property transactions treated as Business Purpose loans. (PDF 3, PDF 4)
• A fee is charged if the borrower pays off the loan early by refinancing, selling, or making excess payments. (PDF 3)
• The prepayment penalty may be assessed between 1 and 5 years after the Note execution date. (PDF 3, PDF 4)
• The penalty structure is six (6) months of interest on prepayments exceeding 20% of the original principal balance. (PDF 3, PDF 4)
• The penalty can be disclosed within the Note or in a separate rider. (PDF 4)
• State-specific conditions for prepayment penalties: (PDF 3)
  - Allowed: Alabama, Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado (with 'Loan Product Choice Disclosure'), Connecticut, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Idaho, Indiana, Iowa, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New York, North Carolina (if loan >$100,000), North Dakota, Oklahoma, Oregon (with 'Oregon PPP Disclosure'), Pennsylvania (if loan >$319,777 or on 3-4 unit), South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas (on non-owner occupied), Utah, Vermont, Virginia (if loan >$75,000), Washington (if Fixed Rate), West Virginia, Wisconsin (with 'Wisconsin PPP Disclosure'), Wyoming.
  - Not Allowed: Alaska, District of Columbia, Kansas, Maryland, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Mexico, Ohio, Rhode Island.
  - Illinois: Allowed only to Legal Entity; no penalty if APR exceeds 8% unless borrower is a corporation or LLC.
  - New Jersey: Allowed to Legal Entities only; LLCs may be considered with requirements.
